articles.title: About This Workshop
articles.contents:
The purpose of this workshop is to elicit expert knowledge on the current geographic range, habitat suitability, and ecological traits of established invasive species. Data will be collated across participants to derive estimates of current distribution as well as project future range shifts or expansions over time.
Food
Lunch will be provided. Coffee and snack will be available throughout the day.
Prior to attendance
Participants are asked to complete a trial of the Shiny app to familiarize themselves with the process before attending the workshop (for 3 spp.). Please complete your three species by April 21st.
What to bring
Laptop or tablet
Your thoughtful contributions
Questions
For any further information regarding this workshop and how these results will be used, please contact Brett Scheffers at brett.scheffers@ufl.edu

articles.title: Tutorial for using the Shiny app
articles.description: Quantifying species habitat suitability and prevalence
articles.contents: Recorded tutorial for interacting with the Shiny app.

articles.title: SECASC Invasive Species Expert Elicitation Workshop
articles.description:
April 27-28, 2022
Austin Cary Forest Campus
University of Florida, Gainesville, FL
articles.contents:
This expert elicitation workshop aims to use expert elicitation to assess invasive species risk throughout the southeastern US. We have developed a purpose built web application that will be used to collate expert knowledge to produce models of current species distributions and future distributions under climate change. The workshop would focus on approximately 10-15 invasive species that are currently, or have the potential to be, highly detrimental to ecosystems of the SE US. These species come from our initial meeting over Zoom in Autumn 2021 where we ranked species. Thus, this first workshop is quite focused on taxonomic expertise in distribution and ecological/trait data. We will then have a second workshop where we explore management options in light of outputs from workshop 1.
This workshop is supported by the Southeast Climate Adaptation Science Center and is hosted by the University of Florida. The workshop leads are:
Brett Scheffers, Assistant Professor
Luke Evans, Post-doc
Alex Baecher, PhD candidate
Josh Cullen, Post-doc
Invited participants will provide their insight on invasive species habitat suitability and prevalence through an interactive web application created with R Shiny. This web app can be accessed from the ‘App’ tab at the top of the page or through the link to shinyapps.io.

articles.title: Workshop Objectives
articles.contents:
For a list of invasive and potentially invasive species. We will…
Derive a composite estimate (across participants) of habitat suitability
Derive a composite estimate of species relative prevalence across the landscape
Derive estimates of detectability
Compile and/or verify a list of ecologically relevant traits for modeling
Assess current data availability (e.g., location and survey data) for calibration and validation of models
Discuss ongoing and possible management options for scenario-based modeling
Identify future products and collaborative outputs for workshop participants

articles.title: Workshop Itinerary
articles.contents:
April 27, 2022
8:00 am      - Shuttle pickup at hotel 
9:00 am - 10:00 am      - Meet and greet      - Opening presentation by Brett Scheffers with overview of project      - Introduction to virtual maps (Josh Cullen) 
10:30 am - 11:00 am      - Coffee/tea break      - Species detectability exercise 
11:00 am - 12:30 pm      - Completion of virtual maps by all participants 
12:30 pm - 1:30 pm      - Lunch      - Species detectability exercise 
1:30 pm - 3:00 pm      - Breakout groups to discuss, review, and populate checklists of life-history and        physiology traits needed for connectivity modeling (e.g., thermal tolerances,        reproductive output, etc) 
3:00 pm - 3:30 pm      - Coffee/tea break      - Species detectability exercise 
3:30 pm - 5:00 pm      - TBD - e.g., whole group discussion of data compilation (e.g., existing occurrence        data, suitability models, etc) 
5:00 pm - 8:00 pm      - Shuttle back to hotel      - Optional happy hour in town - TBD      - Optional dinner - TBD 

April 28, 2022
8:30 am      - Shuttle pickup at hotel      - For those flying out today, please bring luggage to workshop for afternoon departure 
9:00 am - 10:30 am      - Review and discuss processed expert elicited maps; maps will be generated        overnight from data collected on Day 1 and participants will rate each map 
10:30 am - 11:00 am      - Coffee/tea break      - Species detectability exercise 
11:00 am - 12:30 pm      - Review and discuss processed expert elicited maps; maps will be generated        overnight from data collected on Day 1 and participants will rate each map      - Mapping additional species in App if time allows 
12:30 pm - 1:30 pm      - Lunch      - Species detectability exercise 
1:30 pm - 3:00 pm      - Discussion of modeling approaches for checklist species      - Compile and provide list of management options 
3:00 pm - 3:30 pm      - Coffee/tea break 
3:30 pm - 5:00 pm      - Next steps and action items 
5:30 pm      - Shuttle back to hotel 
7:00 pm      - Dinner location TBA (attendance optional)
